body.div:
"Dear, dearElizabeth"Iexclaimed
when I had read herletter"–Iwill write
instantlyand relieve them from the
great painthey must feel."
I wrote, and this exertion greatly
fatigued me ; b y ut my convalescence was
had
commencedand went on
proceeded
regularly–in
another fortnight I was able to
leave my chamber.
______
Chap. 8
one of my first duties on my recovery was
to introduce Clerval to the
^
several professors of
the university.And in doing thisIunder
went torments a kind of roughusage
that ill befitten befitt ed ing the wounds that
my mind had sustained. Ever since the
fatalnight –the end of mylabours &
thebeginning of mymisfortunes (
I had
conceived a violent antipathy even to
the name of Ch Chemistry Natural Philosophy .When I was other
wise quite restored tohealththe sight of a
Chemical instrumentbrought on
again renewed all
^
the agony of my my
^ nervous symtoms. Lo
Henry sawthisand had p packed up removed
all my
machines in a chest apparatus from my
che view he had also
changed my room ap p artment, for he perceived that
I hada acquired
disliketothe room which had
previously been myworkshop.But these
cares of Clerval were thrown away made of no avail when
I visited the professors.even my excellent
M. Waldman inflicted torture when
he praisedwith the kindness and warmth,
the astonishing progress that I had made
in the sciences. He soon perceived my
that I
dislike d of thesubject, butnot guessing
the realcausehe attributed to it
my feelings
to modesty on hearing myself praised
he therefore
andchanged the subject from
myimprovement,to the science itself,
with an a desireas I evidentlysaw
of drawing friend me out.
K Kind
friend he tortured me without but
it How cruel is What could I do?
He meant to please and me & he
tortured
tormented
me it was
I feltas if he had
placed carefullyone byone placed in my
view those instruments which were
to be afterwards used in putting me to a
slow and cruel dre death. I writhed
under his words, yet dared not shew
my the pain I felt. Clerval, whose
eyes and feelings were always quick
indi s cerningthe sensations ofothers
declined thesubject alledging in
^
his
ignorance& the conversation took
a more general turn. I thankedhim
from my heart, but I did not speak.
I plainly sawthat he was surprised,
but he never attempted to draw
my secret fromme,and although
I loved him with a mixture of
love
affection and reverence that knewno
bounds,yet I could never
pr persuade
myself to confide to him that event
which was so often present to my
thoughts,but which I feared the detail
to another would only impress more deeply.
M r .Krempe was not
^
equally
docile yet &weak
as my illness had made me
in mythen
conditionof
almost in
supportable
sensitivenesshis harsh
blunteconiumsgave me even more
pain that than the benevolent
approbation of M. Waldman —"Dam m n
"the fellow,"criedhe "Why M r . Clerval
"I tellyou he has beaut outstript
"us all– aystare if youpleasebut
"itisnevertheless true –A youngster
"whobut two threeyearsagobelieved
"Cornelius Agrippa
to be
^
as firmly as the
gospelhas
"nowset himself at the head of
"the university& if he is not soon
"pulled downwe shall all be out
"of countenance.—Aye, Aye,continued
"heobserving my countenance
^
face ex
pressive of suffering "Mr. f
Franken
stein ismodestan excellent quality in
"ayoungman;Young men should be
"diffidentofthemselvesyouknow M
" Clerval;I was myself whenyoungbut
"one soon growsoutof that."
M
Krempe had now commenced
the subject of his own praise an eulogy on himself and that
happily turned the conversation
fromthesubject that was so painful agonizing
to me.
Clervalwas no natural philosopher.
His imagination was too vividfor
the minutiæ of science.
La Lan
guages were his
chief
^
principal study for he
wished toopen a fieldfor
^
him
self-instruc
tion on his return – Greek Persian
& Arabic & Hebrew gainedhis atten
tion when
X
so soon as X
he had become
perfect
ly master of the Greek & Latin langua
ges. For my own partidleness had
ever been irksome tomeand
now that Iwished tofly from reflec
tion and hated my formerstudies
a
Ifoundgreat relief in being the
fellow pupil of
withmy fr friendand
I not a only found
instruct not only instruc
tion but consolation in the works of
the orientalists.
There is something soothing
Their melancholy issoothingand their
joyelevatingto a degree I neverbefore
experienced in
reading
^
studying
any
^
the authors of any other books.
^
country.
When you read
s their
li writingslife
appears to consist in a warm sun
andgardensofroses – inthe smiles &
tears
frowns of a fairenemyand the fire
that consumes your ownheart
How different from theman ^
l y& warlike
heroical
poet ry of Greece &Rome.
Summer passed away in these
studies
occupations
& my return to Geneva was
fixed for the latter end ofAutum m n but
beingdelayed by severalaccidentswinter
& snow arrived, and the roads were
deemed impassableand my return
^
journey
delayed
was
retarted untillthe
^
ensuing spring. I felt this
delay verybitterly ^
forI longed to see my
native c t ownand my belovedfriends
and my return had only been delayed
solongfrom an unwillingness to leave
Clerval in a strangetownbefore he
had become acquainted withits in
habitants. Thewinter ^
however was however
s spent
a cheerful ly one and although the
spring was uncommonlylatewhen
itcameits beauty compensated
for its dilatoriness. Ma The month
of Maywasalready finis end com
pleated,andI expected daily the
letter thatwas to fix the date of
my return
^
departure, When Henry proposed
a pedestrian tour inenvirons of
Ingolstadtthat I might bidfarewell
to the country I had so long in
habited.–Iacceededwith pleasure to
thispropos al
^
ition –I was fond ofExercise
and Clerval had always been my
favourite companion in j
^
the rambles
of this nature that I had taken
among the scenes of my native coun
try.We passed a fortnight in these
perambulations.My health and spirits had long
beenrestoredand they gainedadd i it ional vigour
from the salubrious air , X
I breathed,
X
the natural
incidents of
our progress X
and the
conversation of my friend. Study had before
renderedmeunsocia ble l, –I had shunnedthe face
companyof myfellow beingsBut Clerval
called forth the better feelings of myheart.
he again taught me to love the aspect
ofnatureand the cheerful faces of chil
dren. Excellent Friend! How sincerely did you
lovemeand endeavour to elevate my
mind untillit was on a level with
yourown.A selfishpersuit e had cramp
ed and narrowed it
^
me untillyourgentle
ness& affection warmed & opened it
^
my senses . and
nowI
^
now became the same happy creature
whoa few years ago,loving& beloved by
all, had no sorrow orcare – I and when
happy so soul was more fitted than mine
for feeling delight in inanimate nature
X
X had the
power of
bes
bo towing on
me the most
delightful
sensations —
A serene sky filled and verdant
s fields
filled me with extasy.– t T he ^
presentseason was indeed
divine –the flowers of spring blossomed
^
bloomed in the
hedgeswhile those of summer were al
ready inbud–I dis was not disturbedby
thoughtsthatduring thepreceeding
yearpressed uponme not withstand
ing my endeavours to throw themoff with an invincibleburthen.
Henry a rejoiced
im in my gaietyand
sincerelysympathizedin my joy feelings –he exer
ted himself to amuse me, while he expressed
thefeelingsthat al filled his
mind
^
soul .The
resources of his mind on this occasion
were trulyastonishing. As we rested during
the sultry heat of noon he invented
his conversation was full ofimagination
and very often, in imitation of the persi
an&Arabic writers, he invented tales
of great
^
wonderful fancy andinterrest.At other
times he repeated my favouritepoems
or drew me out intoargumentswhich
he supported with great ingenuity.
We returned
^
to our colledge on a sunday–thepea
santsweredancingand every one we
met appearedjoyfulandhappy –my
own spirits werehighand I bounded
along with a feelings of
hilarity unbound
ed
unbridled joy and hilarity.
